items.title: Istanbul police detain 115 suspected ISIS members believed planning Christmas attacks in Turkey
items.summary_auto: Turkish authorities have detained 115 suspected ISIS members they believe were planning to carry out attacks on Christmas and new year celebrations in the country, the chief prosecutor's office said Thursday.

items.title: Pope Leo's 1st Christmas sermon decries treatment of Palestinians in Gaza, destruction from wars
Pickleball's on the rise in Canada. So are injuries from playing it
items.summary_auto: As the sport grows in Canada, medical professionals say they are seeing the effect it is having on people physically.

items.title: Pope Leo's 1st Christmas sermon decries treatment of Palestinians in Gaza, harm of wars on the 'defenceless'
items.summary_auto: Pope Leo gave his first Christmas sermon on Thursday from St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican, decrying conditions for Palestinians in Gaza in an unusually direct appeal during what is normally a solemn, spiritual service.

items.title: One year into Trump 2.0: Here’s how much America has radically changed on his watch
How internet sleuths are un-redacting some of the Epstein files
items.summary_auto: While Democratic legislators, victims of Jeffrey Epstein and their lawyers have complained about the number of blacked-out pages and passages in the files released by the U.S. Department of Justice,  internet sleuths have figured out ways to un-redact some of the documents.

items.title: Russia is about to start staging plays at the Mariupol theatre it bombed
items.summary_auto: Russian state media reported that the theatre is slated to officially reopen on Dec. 25, and that plays will start being staged there at some point in the new year. Russian occupation authorities have renamed it the Mariupol Republican Order of the Badge of Honour Russian Drama Theatre, and on its website write that the theatre is being reborn, like the entire city of Mariupol.

items.title: Carney reflects on jump into politics at an 'important time,' key subjects in year-end interview
Under the streets of Naples, a social collective bets on locals, culture to help a rough neighbourhood thrive
items.summary_auto: Below the long-isolated and neglected Neapolitan neighbourhood of Rione Sanità, a vast underground network of ancient burial chambers remained mostly forgotten for centuries. Today, a social co-operative ihas turned the cultural heritage of the Catacombs of San Gennaro into local jobs, skills and a steady draw of tourists.

items.title: Need a 'real' villain? Call Kevin O'Leary. Why the Shark Tank star shows up in Marty Supreme
items.summary_auto: In what might be some of the most WTF casting this year, Canadian businessman-turned-TV-host, Trump pal and wannabe political leader Kevin O'Leary features prominently in the new film Marty Supreme.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Christmas celebrations from around the world
items.summary_auto: From meat auctions to surf competitions, here are some Christmas events and celebrations happening around the world.

items.title: Unions, PCs skeptical as Manitoba premier promises end to long waits in health care in 2026
items.summary_auto: Some health-care leaders are questioning how Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew can confidently declare his government will end long waits for health-care services by the end of 2026.

items.title: A campaign tried to get 100 Christmas cards to a 100-year-old B.C. veteran. He has 700 and counting
items.summary_auto: A campaign for one of Canada's few remaining Second World War veterans, Irv Radatzke, to receive 100  Christmas cards this holiday season has exceeded expectations while also brightening his time in hospital.

items.title: After weeks of vote counting, Trump-backed candidate wins Honduras presidential election
items.summary_auto: Trump-backed candidate Nasry Asfura won Honduras' presidential election, electoral authorities said Wednesday afternoon, ending a weeks-long count that has whittled away at the credibility of the Central American nation's fragile electoral system.

items.title: Winter storm inundates California with heavy rain, mudslides and whiteout chaos
items.summary_auto: A powerful winter storm swept across California on Wednesday, with heavy rain and gusty winds leading to evacuation warnings for mudslides in the south, bringing near white-out snow conditions in the mountains and hazardous travel for millions of holiday drivers.

items.title: Why this 80-year-old Anglican deacon courted arrest for his climate activism
items.summary_auto: Faith leaders are increasingly speaking out, and even facing arrest, for their climate activism.

items.title: 'Truly a Christmas miracle': Black bear cub survives being burned in northern B.C.
items.summary_auto: Rescuers said the clock was ticking on whether the cub would even survive the night, given it was at least a nine-hour drive away in ideal conditions — let alone in  bitterly cold conditions that were enveloping the province throughout the week.

items.title: What we know about CECOT, the brutal mega-prison at the heart of the recent 60 Minutes controversy
Multiple Canadian businesses listed on U.S.-based 'gift card' site without permission
RCMP say 70 trees deliberately cut, left to die in Powell River, B.C.
items.summary_auto: Police say municipal staff inspected the site and found the trees were left standing but had been cut around their bases, likely with a chainsaw. Many of the trees that were cut were older-growth Douglas fir trees, valuable to the community and ecosystem.

items.title: 5th person hospitalized in E. coli outbreak linked to Pillsbury brand Pizza Pops
items.summary_auto:
The Public Health Agency of Canada is reporting a fifth hospitalization in an E. coli outbreak linked to recalled Pillsbury
brand Pizza Pops. The federal agency says 23 people in seven provinces got sick with the bacterial illness after eating or handling
certain flavours of the frozen snack between early October and late November.
